intro: Acaena petiolulata, commonly known as the small-leaf burrplant, is a low-growing shrub native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit and is often found in coastal and subalpine environments. The plant produces small, prickly fruits that contain seeds surrounded by a hairy, spiny husk. Its leaves are typically narrow and have a distinctive, serrated edge. Acaena petiolulata plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for native invertebrates.

distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena petiolulata was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the broader introduction of the Acaena genus, which includes several species native to South America.
